bug.short_desc: Add a flag to class documentation stating what version it was introduced in

long_desc.thetext:
The issue is best described by a use case, one that I followed myself.
1) qooxdoo twitter account posts status: https://twitter.com/#!/qooxdoo/status/58081964229529600
2) Follow the link in the tweet to the API docs http://demo.qooxdoo.org/current/apiviewer/#qx.dev.unit.MMock
3) Notice that there is no way to see if the qx.dev.unit.MMock class is available to version 1.3.x of the framework
There is a workaround by replacing the /current/ part of the URL to /1.3.x/ , which in the case above shows an alert message "Unknown class: qx.dev.unit.MMock"
This would be a great addition to the already great API viewer application. For an example of what I am talking about you can see in any of the Qt Class documentation what version the class was introduced in.
for a random example see : http://doc.qt.nokia.com/4.7/qabstractxmlreceiver.html
"This class was introduced in Qt 4.4."
Thomas, do you have an idea how we could get something like that automatically? It much work to get every class updated we already have.

We could scan the SVN logs for "added" entries, and then match the corresponding revision numbers to releases.
- But we should carefully consider how this information shall be applied. - We had cases where classes were moved/renamed. What would be their "added" status?! - There is the righteous question if the same tagging should be applied to methods. But would that be overkill?! - How should we go about future new classes? - We could add a @versionadded JSDoc tag, which has to be present with every class (which could be enforced by the apidoc generation process). - As we are not adding new classes every other day, I guess this would be an acceptable burden for API doc writers.
How much time would we need to get that done and where is the major part of the work located?
